prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Imaging: The target is compact and we do not expect to resolve it spatially. Even if it shows resolved structure, we will still integrated everything to improve the signal-to-noise S/N. We do not expect any missing flux, and all emissions are within the central 1/3 of the beam.
Sensitivity: The expected source flux density for the peak of 13CO line is about 2 mJy, the full width zero intensity (FWZI) line width is about 500 km/s at 3 mm. At desired spectral resolution of 100 km/s, we expect to have reach a rms of 0.3 mJy and a signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio of 8.
Correlator: We request four base bands working in spectral line mode, and each with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and a frequency resolution of 7.8 MHz which is 16 times averaged from the origin.
Bandpass accuracy: We request *normal* Bandpass solution.
Scheduling constraints: No special constraints.
Data rate: 1.4 MB/s

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP.17b 4-3

Correlator: We request four base bands working in spectral line mode, and each with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and a frequency resolution of 7.8 MHz which is 16 times averaged from the origin.
Bandpass accuracy: We request *normal* Bandpass solution.
Scheduling constraints: No special constraints.
Data rate: 1.4 MB/s

Imaging: The target is compact and we do not expect to resolve it spatially. Even if it shows resolved structure, we will still integrated everything to improve the signal-to-noise S/N. We do not expect any missing flux, and all emissions are within the central 1/3 of the beam.
Sensitivity: The expected source flux density for the peak of 12CO line is about 40 mJy, the full width zero intensity (FWZI) line width is about 500 km/s at 2 mm. At desired spectral resolution of 100 km/s, we expect to have reach a rms of 0.6 mJy and a signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio of 60.
Correlator: We request four base bands working in spectral line mode, and each with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and a frequency resolution of 7.8 MHz which is 16 times averaged from the origin.
Bandpass accuracy: We request *normal* Bandpass solution.
Scheduling constraints: No special constraints.
Data rate: 1.4 MB/s
The overhead is > 30%, but we should already reach the required sensitivity and S/N ratio.

Scheduling constraints: No special constraints.
Data rate: 1.4 MB/s.
The overhead time is about >30%, but we should already achieved the requested S/N ratio.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The physical conditions of molecular gas in galaxies and the impact of star formation on the emergent stellar IMF, are essential themes in galaxy evolution, especially at high redshifts. Here we propose to observe the ladders of isotopic CO lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O) in three of the brightest known, strongly lensed, star-forming galaxies at z~2, selected on the basis of existing, strong 12CO detections. The ratios between these isotopic CO transitions inform us about the historic stellar populations because of the different nucleosynthesis of Carbon and Oxygen. With these data, we will be able to decouple the optical depth and observed intensity ratios using Bayesian Large Velocity Gradient (LVG) modeling. The results will also serve as critical analogues to compare with galaxies at the local Universe. Combining our unique sample with the transformational power of ALMA, we have a unique opportunity to probe the history of the initial mass function (IMF) and the physical conditions of star-forming gas in these galaxies, at the peak epoch of star formation in the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Royal Observatory, Edinburgh, Science and Technology Facilities Council
